intro: Justicia tabascina, commonly known as Mexican vervain, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, featuring upright stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of vibrant blue or purple tubular flowers that bloom in the summer months. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for ornamental gardens. Its showy flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological value.
